Type.Name: SByte

TypeSignature.Value: .class public sequential sealed serializable SByte extends System.ValueType implements System.IComparable, System.IFormattable
public struct SByte : IComparable, IComparable<sbyte>, IConvertible, IEquatable<sbyte>, IFormattable

.class public sequential ansi serializable sealed beforefieldinit int8 extends System.ValueType implements class System.IComparable, class System.IComparable`1<int8>, class System.IConvertible, class System.IEquatable`1<int8>, class System.IFormattable

Type.ThreadingSafetyStatement: This type is safe for multithreaded operations.

remarks.para: The value type represents integers with values ranging from negative 128 to positive 127.

block.para: The type is not CLS-compliant. The CLS-compliant alternative type is . can be used instead to replace a positive value that ranges from zero to . For more information about CLS compliance, see Common Language Specification.

remarks.para: provides methods to compare instances of this type, convert the value of an instance to its string representation, and convert the string representation of a number to an instance of this type.
For information about how format specification codes control the string representation of value types, see Formatting Types.

summary.para: Represents an 8-bit signed integer.

remarks.para: This method implements the interface and performs slightly better than the method because it does not have to convert the parameter to an object.

Depending on your programming language, it might be possible to code a method where the parameter type has fewer bits (is narrower) than the instance type. This is possible because some programming languages perform an implicit widening conversion that represents the parameter as a type with as many bits as the instance.

For example, suppose the instance type is and the parameter type is . The Microsoft C# compiler generates instructions to represent the value of the parameter as an object, then generates a method that compares the values of the instance and the parameter representation.
Consult your programming language's documentation to determine if its compiler performs implicit widening conversions on numeric types.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig static int8 Parse(string s)
public static sbyte Parse (string s);
.method public static hidebysig int8 Parse(string s) cil managed

Docs.exception: is not in the correct style.
represents a number greater than or less than .

remarks.para: The parameter contains a number of the form:
[ws][sign]digits[ws]
Elements in square brackets ([ and ]) are optional. The following table describes each element.

description.para: A sequence of digits ranging from 0 to 9.

remarks.para: The parameter is interpreted using the style. In addition to the byte value's decimal digits, only leading and trailing spaces with a leading positive or negative sign are allowed. To explicitly define the style elements that can be present in , use either the or the method.

The parameter is parsed by using the formatting information in a that is initialized for the current system culture. For more information, see . To parse a string by using the formatting information of some other culture, use the method.

summary.para: Converts the string representation of a number to its 8-bit signed integer equivalent.

returns.para: An 8-bit signed integer that is equivalent to the number contained in the parameter.

Docs.param: A string that represents a number to convert. The string is interpreted using the style.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig static int8 Parse(string s, valuetype System.Globalization.NumberStyles style)
public static sbyte Parse (string s, System.Globalization.NumberStyles style);
.method public static hidebysig int8 Parse(string s, valuetype System.Globalization.NumberStyles style) cil managed

Docs.exception: is not in the correct style.
represents a number greater than or less than .
Docs.param: A string that contains a number to convert. The string is interpreted using the style specified by .
A bitwise combination of the enumeration values that indicates the style elements that can be present in . A typical value to specify is .

remarks.para: The parameter defines the style elements (such as white space or the positive or negative sign symbol) that are allowed in the parameter for the parse operation to succeed. It must be a combination of bit flags from the enumeration.
Depending on the value of , the parameter may include the following elements:
[ws][$][sign]digits[.fractional_digits][E[sign]exponential_digits][ws]
If includes , the parameter may contain the following elements:
[ws]hexdigits[ws]
Elements in square brackets ([ and ]) are optional. The following table describes each element.

description.para: Optional white space. White space can appear at the beginning of if includes the flag, and it can appear at the end of if style includes the flag.
A culture-specific currency symbol. Its position in the string is defined by the property of the current culture. The current culture's currency symbol can appear in if includes the flag.

An optional sign. The sign can appear at the beginning of if includes the flag, and it can appear at the end of if includes the flag. Parentheses can be used in to indicate a negative value if includes the flag.
A sequence of digits from 0 through 9.
A culture-specific decimal point symbol. The current culture's decimal point symbol can appear in if includes the flag.
One or more occurrences of the digit 0-9 if includes the flag, or one or more occurrences of the digit 0 if it does not. Fractional digits can appear in only if includes the flag.
The "e" or "E" character, which indicates that the value is represented in exponential (scientific) notation. The parameter can represent a number in exponential notation if includes the flag.
One or more occurrences of the digit 0-9. The parameter can represent a number in exponential notation if includes the flag.
A sequence of hexadecimal digits from 0 through f, or 0 through F.

remarks.para: A string with decimal digits only (which corresponds to the style) always parses successfully. Most of the remaining members control elements that may be present, but are not required to be present, in the input string. The following table indicates how individual members affect the elements that may be present in .

description.para: Elements permitted in s in addition to digits
The decimal point (.) and fractional_digits elements. However, if does not include the flag, fractional_digits must consist of only one or more 0 digits; otherwise, an is thrown.
The "e" or "E" character, which indicates exponential notation, along with exponential_digits.
The ws element at the beginning of .
The ws element at the end of .
The sign element in the form of parentheses enclosing the numeric value.
The group separator (,) element. Although the group separator can appear in , it must be preceded by only one or more 0 digits.

remarks.para: If the flag is used, must be a hexadecimal value. The only other flags that can be combined with it are and . (The enumeration includes a composite number style, , that includes both white-space flags.)

block.para: If the parameter is the string representation of a hexadecimal number, it cannot be preceded by any decoration (such as 0x or &h) that differentiates it as a hexadecimal number. This causes the parse operation to throw an exception.

remarks.para: If represents a hexadecimal number, the method interprets the high-order bit of the byte as a sign bit.
The parameter is parsed by using the formatting information in a object that is initialized for the current system culture. To use the formatting information of some other culture, call the overload.

summary.para: Converts the string representation of a number in a specified style to its 8-bit signed integer equivalent.

returns.para: An 8-bit signed integer that is equivalent to the number specified in .

Docs.param: A string that contains a number to convert. The string is interpreted using the style specified by .
A bitwise combination of the enumeration values that indicates the style elements that can be present in . A typical value to specify is .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig static int8 Parse(string s, class System.IFormatProvider provider)
public static sbyte Parse (string s, IFormatProvider provider);
.method public static hidebysig int8 Parse(string s, class System.IFormatProvider provider) cil managed

Docs.exception: is not in the correct style.
represents a number greater than or less than .

remarks.para: The parameter contains a number of the form:
[ws][sign]digits[ws]
Elements in square brackets ([ and ]) are optional. The following table describes each element.

description.para: A sequence of digits ranging from 0 to 9.

remarks.para: The parameter is interpreted using the style. In addition to the byte value's decimal digits, only leading and trailing spaces with a leading sign are allowed. To explicitly define the style elements with the culture-specific formatting information that can be present in , use the method.

The parameter is an implementation whose method returns a object that provides culture-specific information about the format of . There are three ways to use the parameter to supply custom formatting information to the parse operation:

item.para: You can pass the actual object that provides formatting information. (Its implementation of simply returns itself.)
You can pass a object that specifies the culture whose formatting is to be used. Its property provides formatting information.
You can pass a custom implementation. Its method must instantiate and return the object that provides formatting information.

remarks.para: If is null, the object for the current culture is used.

summary.para: Converts the string representation of a number in a specified culture-specific format to its 8-bit signed integer equivalent.

returns.para: An 8-bit signed integer that is equivalent to the number specified in .

Docs.param: A string that represents a number to convert. The string is interpreted using the style.
An object that supplies culture-specific formatting information about . If is null, the thread current culture is used.

description.para: Optional white space. White space can appear at the beginning of if includes the flag, and it can appear at the end of if includes the flag.

remarks.para: A string with decimal digits only (which corresponds to the style) always parses successfully. Most of the remaining members control elements that may be present, but are not required to be present, in this input string. The following table indicates how individual members affect the elements that may be present in .

description.para: Elements permitted in in addition to digits
The decimal point (.) and fractional_digits elements. However, if style does not include the flag, fractional_digits must consist of only one or more 0 digits; otherwise, an is thrown.
The "e" or "E" character, which indicates exponential notation, along with exponential_digits.
The ws element at the beginning of .
The ws element at the end of .
Parentheses before and after digits to indicate a negative value.
The group separator (,) element. Although the group separator can appear in , it must be preceded by only one or more 0 digits.

remarks.para: If the flag is used, must be a hexadecimal value. The only other flags that can be combined with it are and . (The enumeration includes a composite number style, , that includes both white-space flags.)

The parameter is an implementation whose method returns a object that provides culture-specific information about the format of . There are three ways to use the parameter to supply custom formatting information to the parse operation:

item.para: You can pass the actual object that provides formatting information. (Its implementation of simply returns itself.)

summary.para: Converts the string representation of a number that is in a specified style and culture-specific format to its 8-bit signed equivalent.

returns.para: An 8-bit signed byte value that is equivalent to the number specified in the parameter.

Docs.param: A string that contains the number to convert. The string is interpreted by using the style specified by .
A bitwise combination of the enumeration values that indicates the style elements that can be present in . A typical value to specify is .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual string ToString()
public override string ToString ();
.method public hidebysig virtual instance string ToString() cil managed

remarks.para: The method formats an value in the default ("G", or general) format of the current culture. If you want to specify a different format or culture, use the other overloads of the method, as follows:

The return value is formatted using the general numeric format specifier ("G") The string representation of the value includes a negative sign if its value is negative, and a sequence of digits ranging from 0 to 9 without leading zeros. The negative sign is defined by the object for the current culture.
To define the formatting of the signed byte value's string representation, call the method.

summary.para: Converts the numeric value of this instance to its equivalent string representation.

returns.para: The string representation of the value of this instance, consisting of a negative sign if the value is negative, and a sequence of digits ranging from 0 to 9 with no leading zeroes.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public final hidebysig virtual string ToString(class System.IFormatProvider provider)
public string ToString (IFormatProvider provider);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance string ToString(class System.IFormatProvider provider) cil managed

remarks.para: The method formats an value in the default ("G", or general) format of a specified culture. If you want to specify a different format or the current culture, use the other overloads of the method, as follows:

The parameter is an implementation. Its method returns a object that provides culture-specific information about the format of the string returned by this method. If is null, the value is formatted using the object of the current culture. The only property of the object that controls the string representation of the value using the general format specifier is , which defines the character that represents the negative sign.
The parameter can be one of the following:

item.para: A object that represents the culture that supplies formatting information.
The object that supplies formatting information.
A custom object that implements . Its method returns the object that supplies formatting information.

summary.para: Converts the numeric value of this instance to its equivalent string representation using the specified culture-specific format information.

returns.para: The string representation of the value of this instance, as specified by .

Docs.param: An object that supplies culture-specific formatting information.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance string ToString(string format)
public string ToString (string format);
.method public hidebysig instance string ToString(string format) cil managed

remarks.para: The method formats an value in a specified format by using the conventions of the current culture. If you want to use the default ("G", or general) format or specify a different culture, use the other overloads of the method, as follows:

The parameter can be any valid standard numeric format specifier, or any combination of custom numeric format specifiers. If is equal to or is null, the return value of the current object is formatted with the general format specifier ("G"). If is any other value, the method throws a .
The .NET Framework provides extensive formatting support, which is described in greater detail in the following formatting topics:

item.para: For more information about numeric format specifiers, see Standard Numeric Format Strings and Custom Numeric Format Strings.
For more information about support for formatting in the .NET Framework, see Formatting Types.

remarks.para: The format of the returned string is determined by the object for the current culture. Depending on the parameter, this object controls symbols such as the negative sign, the group separator, and the decimal point symbol in the output string. To provide formatting information for cultures other than the current culture, call the overload.

summary.para: Converts the numeric value of this instance to its equivalent string representation, using the specified format.

returns.para: The string representation of the value of this instance as specified by .

Docs.param: A standard or custom numeric format string.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public final hidebysig virtual string ToString(string format, class System.IFormatProvider provider)
public string ToString (string format, IFormatProvider provider);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance string ToString(string format, class System.IFormatProvider provider) cil managed

remarks.para: The method formats an value in a specified format of a specified culture. If you want to use default format or culture settings, use the other overloads of the method, as follows:

The parameter can be any valid standard numeric format specifier, or any combination of custom numeric format specifiers. If is equal to or is null, the return value of the current object is formatted with the general format specifier ("G"). If is any other value, the method throws a .
The .NET Framework provides extensive formatting support, which is described in greater detail in the following formatting topics:

item.para: For more information about numeric format specifiers, see Standard Numeric Format Strings and Custom Numeric Format Strings.
For more information about support for formatting in the .NET Framework, see Formatting Types.

remarks.para: The parameter is an implementation. Its method returns a object that provides culture-specific information about the format of the string returned by this method. When the method is invoked, it calls the parameter's method and passes it a object that represents the type. The method then returns the object that provides information for formatting the parameter, such as the negative sign symbol, the group separator symbol, or the decimal point symbol. There are three ways to use the parameter to supply formatting information to the method:

item.para: You can pass a object that represents the culture that supplies formatting information. Its method returns the object that provides numeric formatting information for that culture.
You can pass the actual object that provides numeric formatting information. (Its implementation of just returns itself.)
You can pass a custom object that implements . Its method instantiates and returns the object that provides formatting information.

remarks.para: If is null, the formatting of the returned string is based on the object of the current culture.

summary.para: Converts the numeric value of this instance to its equivalent string representation using the specified format and culture-specific format information.

returns.para: The string representation of the value of this instance as specified by and .

Docs.param: A standard or custom numeric format string.
An object that supplies culture-specific formatting information.
